bug.author: joelrich
bug.summary: Probabilities for logistic regression with sgd are all almost 0 or 1 (but not with lbfgs)
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h4>Issue description</denchmark-h>
When I use optimizer="sgd", the probabilities in output_probabilities are all almost 0 or 1: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4216919/52180346-a3c37300-27e5-11e9-8d4c-70b5aa71c69a.png></denchmark-link>
With optimizer="lbfgs", I get a completely different picture: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4216919/52180396-eab16880-27e5-11e9-8de2-f96e43a829bd.png></denchmark-link>
<denchmark-h:h4>Your environment</denchmark-h>
version of mlpack: mlpack3 3.0.2.post1 (Python) operating system: Ubuntu
<denchmark-h:h4>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>
I cannot share the data, but this is the code I use: from mlpack import logistic_regression
class MlpackLogisticRegression:
def __init__(self, **params): self.params = params self.model = None
def train(self, X, y): output = logistic_regression(training=X, labels=y, **self.params) self.model = output["output_model"]
def predict_proba(self, X): output = logistic_regression(input_model=self.model, test=X) return output["output_probabilities"]
clf = MlpackLogisticRegression(lambda_=0, optimizer="lbfgs", verbose=True) clf.train(X_train, y_train) y_pred = clf.predict_proba(X_test)
pd.Series(y_pred[:,1]).hist() <denchmark-h:h4>Expected behavior</denchmark-h>
I would expect the distributions to be similar. <denchmark-h:h4>Actual behavior</denchmark-h>
See plots above. In case this is not an issue, but just a known limitation of sgd, here some more background. I switched from Scikit Learn to mlpack because of the better performance. Since the performance of sgd is way better than with lbfgs, I would really like to use sgd (or speed up lbfgs somehow).

comments.comment: I encountered this issue before, because my data is linear-separable. I am not sure if here the issue is the same, but it may be one of causes to screen. Other issue can be the parameters of training. May be it worth to plot the trace of accuracy (and precision and recall) during training to see if training converges or not. Hope it is helpful.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/joelrich>@joelrich</denchmark-link> thanks so much for the detailed report. It is really helpful for seeing what is happening. Actually this phenomenon happen when there is no regularization---as <denchmark-link:https://github.com/karlzhang-hhg>@karlzhang-hhg</denchmark-link> pointed out, this can happen if data is linearly separable. So what happens is that the logistic regression loss is minimized as the probabilities for each point converge to 0 and 1. This happens because the parameters of the logistic regression model become very large (thus causing the probabilities of any predicted point to be 0 or 1). A regularization parameter adds the norm of the parameters of the model to the loss function. The level of regularization is controlled by the parameter, which it looks like you have set to 0 (i.e. no regularization). So if you use a greater than 0, the regularization will be applied, which will keep the model parameters from growing too large, which will in turn cause the output probabilities to be further away from 0 or 1. Try your code with, say, lambda_=0.1 and see if that helps. (If not, try larger regularization values.) My bigger question is why L-BFGS didn't converge to the same thing SGD did. Do both optimizers give "good" models that have good accuracy on the training set? Or did L-BFGS converge to something that didn't work?

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/karlzhang-hhg>@karlzhang-hhg</denchmark-link> I work with really noisy data which is not linear separable. This may sound like a contradiction, but my experiments indicate that logistic regression still works better than most other models. If it is relevant, I apply PCA before using logistic regression. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/rcurtin>@rcurtin</denchmark-link> I have just tried lambda_ up to 1e6 and it does not make a big difference. Also, should not SAG of Scikit Learn have the same problem then? It does not. The LBFGS model is as good as I can hope, but still pretty bad. Most likely there is no good model for my task. If you would like to reproduce the issue yourself, then I can send you a link to the data.

Hm, strange that regularization makes no difference here. I'd like to see the parameters that mlpack trains to, but because of the way the bindings are made it's not very easy to extract them. I can make better tools at some point, but for now if you can give me the pickled output pickle.dumps(output['output_model']) (assuming output is the result of your call to mlpack_logistic_regression), I think that I can reconstruct the parameters of the models from that output. It would be useful to have both the L-BFGS output and the SGD output. These outputs will be a big ugly-looking string, which is just the binary-encoded model. You might also consider tuning some parameters of the model---the SGD optimizer may need to be tuned with the step_size and max_iterations options.

Now it gets interesting: With sgd step_size=3e-5 I get a very similar distribution to lbfgs. However, with step_size=1e-4 or step_size=1e-6 the distribution looks quite different. Also, even with max_iterations=100000 sgd is very unstable and the precision varies a lot between different trainings. I guess I just won't use it. I will post some results in the next comment. Don't ask me why, but I could not pickle/output the lbfgs model.
